name: European Turbine Network
legal: a. i. s.b.l. - European non-profit association
membership: ETN has been a member of the European Energy Forum since 2005, and has attended regular events with MEPs on energy issues in the European Parliament.
goal:
The European Turbine Network (ETN) is a non-profit membership association bringing together the entire value chain of turbomachinery technology, representing over 100 members worldwide. ETN addresses the main challenges and concerns of the gas turbine users in technical committees and project groups, composed of experts from the whole value chain, including the power generation and the oil & gas industry, manufacturers of gas turbines (OEMs), the R&D community (universities and research institutes), suppliers & technical service providers and technology consultancies.

The objective of ETN is to strengthen the gas turbine industry and users' market globally in all its facets. Through cooperative efforts and by optimising GT Research and Technology Development (RTD), the association promotes environmentally sound GT technology with reliable and low cost operation. Besides facilitating and coordinating research effort of different parties and bringing together key stakeholders in the turbomachinery community, ETN also presents extensive networking opportunities and acts as solid platform for the exchange of knowledge and experiences. ETN performs technology watch, identifies research gaps and monitors the EU research agenda and policy making at an early stage.

Collaboration across the whole value chain creates a powerful network with the ability to achieve tangible advances in gas turbine technology. A common strategy and research effort between the stakeholders, along with a supportive European Union policy, will enable the expansion and increased competitiveness of the gas turbine sector in Europe. The ETN Secretariat is located in Brussels, Belgium, at heart of the European decision-making process.

ETN was part of the OMSoP project (www.omsop.eu) which was co-funded by the European Commission, Directorate-General for Energy, under the European Union's Seventh Framework Programme (FP7) for Research and Technological Development.
interests: Climate Action, Energy, Environment, Research and innovation
euInitiatives:
ETN mainly follows the future common energy policy developments (2020, 2030 and 2050 goals), climate and environment policy, research policy, in particular the industrial emissions, energy efficiency, Horizon 2020 and Horizon Europe research funding framework, EU emissions trading and carbon capture and storage dossiers.

ETN monitors the ITRE and ENVI Committee meetings in the European Parliament, and the conferences organised by the European Commission on energy, research, climate and environmental initiatives and policies.
